title: How to Make Hot Chocolate Cups

steps.headline: Chop or break up the chocolate into small pieces before melting.
steps.description: This aids the melting process and reduces the chances of burning the chocolate.

steps.headline: Melt the chocolate in a double boiler or in the microwave.
Dip the blown-up balloons in the batch of warm chocolate.
steps.description: Cover the balloon three quarters of the way with chocolate.

steps.headline: Create a thin layer of chocolate around each balloon.
steps.description: Avoid making it too thick; a thin covering works well.

steps.headline: Place the chocolate covered balloons on a sheet of waxed or parchment paper.
steps.description:
Allow them to dry/cool. Allow the chocolate covered balloons to cool for up to 30 minutes. steps.headline: Create the whipping cream.
steps.description:
Combine 1 cup of heavy cream with a teaspoon of sugar. Whip using an electric mixer at high speed until peaks form. Measure ½ a cup of whipping cream and place inside the refrigerator. This cream will sit atop the chocolate mousse cups. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Pour ¼ of a cup of the whipping cream into a small bowl.
steps.description: Sprinkle with the gelatin. Leave for 10 minutes to allow for it to expand.

steps.headline: Combine the chocolate chips, coffee, rum and butter in either a double boiler or the microwave.
Add a pinch of the cayenne powder to the mixture and stir well.
steps.description: Be sure to fully integrate the powder into the cocoa to get a hint of “kicked up” flavor. Do not overwork the mousse––too much whipping will lose its fluffy appeal.

steps.headline: Pop the water balloon once the chocolate has cooled and has set.
Gently pluck the deflated air balloon from inside the cup.
steps.description: Take care not to disturb the chocolate cup when removing the balloon.

steps.headline: Scoop approximately ½ to 1 cup of chocolate mousse into your chocolate cup.
steps.description: The amount will depend upon the size you've made your chocolate cups.

steps.headline: Sprinkle a few chocolate shavings on top.
steps.description: Don't overdo it, but simply add a few slight shavings to add body and crunch to your mousse.

parts.name: Shaping a Handle for the Chocolate Cup

steps.headline: Shape a handle.
steps.description:
This step is optional but it does give a realistic appearance to the chocolate cup if you're prepared to do some more work:
Melt some additional chocolate. Allow to cool until it can be handled. Pour a thin "U"-style shape of melted chocolate onto a tray lined with parchment paper (or onto a silicone sheet). Use your fingers or a tool such as a knife to shape the "U" if needed. Leave to set. Apply the handle using dobs of melted chocolate.

steps.headline: Gently top the cup with the remaining whipping cream.
steps.description: Consider adding some more shaved chocolate or even grate a coffee bean on top. Finished.

Make sure a full 30 minutes has passed if you're unsure whether the chocolate is ready. Gently prick the top of the water balloon with a thin needle to release the air; do this carefully so the balloon doesn't explode. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

Wait for all the air to be released before proceeding to the next step. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Hot-Chocolate-Cups-Step-10Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

Scoop approximately ½ to 1 cup of chocolate mousse into your chocolate cup. The amount will depend upon the size you've made your chocolate cups. Sprinkle a few chocolate shavings on top. Don't overdo it, but simply add a few slight shavings to add body and crunch to your mousse. Shaping a Handle for the Chocolate Cup Shape a handle. This step is optional but it does give a realistic appearance to the chocolate cup if you're prepared to do some more work: Melt some additional chocolate. Allow to cool until it can be handled. Pour a thin "U"-style shape of melted chocolate onto a tray lined with parchment paper (or onto a silicone sheet). Use your fingers or a tool such as a knife to shape the "U" if needed. Leave to set. Apply the handle using dobs of melted chocolate. Gently top the cup with the remaining whipping cream. Consider adding some more shaved chocolate or even grate a coffee bean on top. Finished.
